chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will use the concept of homemade leverage and the weighted average cost of capital to solve for the following questions.

Now that we have the net income, we can solve for the number of dividends received. To do this, we can simply multiply the net income by the quotient of the amount of equity stock that he owns and the company stock. Doing so will give us:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of dividends received}&=\dfrac{\$43,500}{\$360,000} \times \$47,800\\[15 pt]
&=5,776
\end{aligned}$$

He received a total of $5,776$ dividends.

To get the rate of return for this, we can simply take the number of dividends and divide it with the net income of the company. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate of return}&=\dfrac{5,776}{\$47,800}\\[15 pt]
&=0.1208
\end{aligned}$$

The rate of return is $0.1208$ or $12.08\%$

**b.)** For this, we no longer have to solve for the values since they will be the same due to the M&M theorem which states that the value of the company will not be affected by capital structure if we are considering the no-tax approach. This means that since the two companies are identical aside from their capital structure, then that means the cash flow and the rate of return will be the same for both firms.

**c.)** The cost of equity refers to the is the rate at which the investors will be paid accordingly based on their initial investment. To get the cost of equity for ABC, we can simply divide the EBIT by the ABC stock. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of equity for ABC}&=\dfrac{\$73,000}{\$720,000}\\[15 pt]
&=10.14\%
\end{aligned}$$

For the cost of equity for XYZ, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of equity for XYZ}&=\text{(Cost of equity for ABC}-\text{Debt rate})\\
&+\text{Cost of equity for ABC} \times((\text{Stock for ABC}-\text{Stock for XYZ})/\text{Stock for XYZ})
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of equity for XYZ}&=(0.1014-0.007)+0.1014 \times((\$720,000-\$360,000)/\$360,000)\\[15 pt]
&=13.28\%
\end{aligned}$$


The cost for equity for company ABC and company XYZ are $10.14\%$ and $13.28\$, respectively.

**d.)** The weighted average cost of capital (WACC), also known as the cost of capital, refers to the rate that a company is expected to pay on average to all its security holders to finance its assets.

Since Company ABC does not have debt, then its WACC is the same as its cost of equity which is given as $10.14\%$.

Now, in order to solve for the WACC of Company XYZ, we can simply take half of the rate of return and half of the debt rate since as we can see, the stock of XYZ is exactly half the stock of ABC. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC for XYZ}&=\dfrac{13.28\%}{2}+\dfrac{7\%}{2}\\[15 pt]
&=\$10.14\%
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see, the WACC for both companies are the same due to the M&M theorem which states that if taxes are not included in the computation, the value of the company will not be affected by capital structure. This means that since the companies are identical, then the values will be the same for both of them.
